column1: 400	"Just Like Fire (From the Original Motion Picture ""Alice Through The Looking Glass"")"	P!nk	dance pop	2016	163	70	63	-6	11	50	215	1	15	71	"During nineteen fifty-nine
column2: when the public was becoming aware of the Muslims after the New York telecast ""The Hate That Hate Produced
column4: about to retire after twenty years in the U.S. Coast Guard. A friend returned from a visit to her Detroit home and told me of a startling ""black man's"" religion
column6: to which
column7: to her surprise
column8: her entire family was converted. I listened with incredulity to how a ""mad scientist Mr. Yacub"" had genetically ""grafted"" the white race from an original black people. The organization's leader was described as ""The Honorable Elijah Muhammad"" and a ""Minister Malcolm X"" was apparently chief of staff.

column1: When I entered a civilian writing career in New York City
column4: a good deal of provocative material and then proposed an article about the cult to the Reader's Digest. Visiting the Muslim restaurant in Harlem
column5: I asked how I could meet Minister Malcolm X
column6: who was pointed out talking in a telephone booth right behind me. Soon he came out
column7: a gangling
column8: tall
column9: reddish-brown-skinned fellow
column10: at that time thirty-five years old; when my purpose was made known
column11: he bristled
column12: his eyes skewering me from behind the horn-rimmed glasses. ""You're another one of the white man's tools sent to spy!"" he accused me sharply. I said I had a legitimate writing assignment and showed him my letter from the magazine stating that an objective article was wanted
column13: one that would balance what the Muslims said of themselves and what their attackers said about them. Malcolm X snorted that no white man's promise was worth the paper it was on; he would need time to decide if he would cooperate or not. Meanwhile
column14: he suggested that I could attend some of the Harlem Temple Number 7 meetings (""temples"" have since been renamed ""mosques"") which were open to non-Muslim Negroes.

column2: I met some of the converts
column3: all of them neatly dressed and almost embarrassingly polite. Their manners and miens reflected the Spartan personal discipline the organization demanded
column4: and none of them would utter anything but Nation of Islam clichés. Even excellent weather was viewed as a blessing from Allah
column5: with corollary credit due to ""The Honorable Elijah Muhammad.""

column2: Minister Malcolm X told me that he would not take personal responsibility. He said that I should talk about an article with Mr. Muhammad personally. I expressed willingness
column4: and I flew to Chicago. The slightly built
column6: soft-voiced Mr. Muhammad invited me to dinner with his immediate family in his mansion. I was aware that I was being carefully sized up while he talked primarily of F.B.I. and Internal Revenue Service close surveillance of his organization
column7: and of a rumored forthcoming Congressional probe. ""But I have no fear of any of them; I have all that I need -- the truth
column8: Mr. Muhammad said. The subject of my writing an article somehow never got raised
column9: but Malcolm X proved far more cooperative when I returned.

column1: He would sit with me at a white-topped table in the Muslim restaurant and answer guardedly any questions I asked between constant interruptions by calls from the New York press in the telephone booth. When I asked if I could see Muslim activities in some other cities
column2: he arranged with other ministers for me to attend meetings at temples in Detroit

column1: My article entitled ""Mr. Muhammad Speaks"" appeared in early 1960
column2: and it was the first featured magazine notice of the phenomenon. A letter quickly came from Mr. Muhammad appreciating that the article kept my promise to be objective
column3: and Malcolm X telephoned similar compliments. About this time
column4: Dr. C. Eric Lincoln's book The Black Muslims in America was published and the Black Muslims became a subject of growing interest. During 1961 and 1962
column5: the Saturday Evening Post teamed me with a white writer
column6: Al Balk
column7: to do an article; next I did a personal interview of Malcolm X for Playboy magazine
column8: which had promised to print verbatim whatever response he made to my questions. During that interview of several days' duration
column9: Malcolm X repeatedly exclaimed
column10: after particularly blistering anti-Christian or anti-white statements: ""You know that devil's not going to print that!"" He was very much taken aback when Playboy kept its word.

column1: Malcolm X began to warm up to me somewhat. He was most aware of the national periodicals' power
column2: and he had come to regard me
column4: as one avenue of access. Occasionally now he began to telephone me advising me of some radio
column6: or personal speaking appearance he was about to make
column7: or he would invite me to attend some Black Muslim bazaar or other public affair.

column1: I was in this stage of relationship with the Malcolm X who often described himself on the air as ""the angriest black man in America"" when in early 1963 my agent brought me together with a publisher whom the Playboy interview had given the idea of the autobiography of Malcolm X. I was asked if I felt I could get the now nationally known firebrand to consent to telling the intimate details of his entire life. I said I didn't know
column2: but I would ask him. The editor asked me if I could sketch the likely highlights of such a book
column4: I realized how little I knew about the man personally
column5: despite all my interviews. I said that the question had made me aware of how careful Malcolm X had always been to play himself down and to play up his leader Elijah Muhammad.

column4: was that I had heard Malcolm X refer in passing to his life of crime and prison before he became a Black Muslim; that several times he had told me: ""You wouldn't believe my past
column5: and that I had heard others say that at one time he had peddled dope and women and committed armed robberies.

column1: I knew that Malcolm X had an almost fanatical obsession about time. ""I have less patience with someone who doesn't wear a watch than with anyone else
column2: for this type is not time-conscious
column3: he had once told me. ""In all our deeds
column4: the proper value and respect for time determines success or failure."" I knew how the Black Muslim membership was said to increase wherever Malcolm X lectured
column5: and I knew his pride that Negro prisoners in most prisons were discovering the Muslim religion as he had when he was a convict. I knew he professed to eat only what a Black Muslim (preferably his wife Betty) had cooked and he drank innumerable cups of coffee which he lightened with cream
column6: commenting wryly
column7: ""Coffee is the only thing I like integrated."" Over our luncheon table
column8: I told the editor and my agent how Malcolm X could unsettle non-Muslims -- as
column9: for instance
column10: once when he offered to drive me to a subway
column11: I began to light a cigarette and he drily observed
column12: ""That would make you the first person ever to smoke in this automobile.""

column1: Malcolm X gave me a startled look when I asked him if he would tell his life story for publication. It was one of the few times I have ever seen him uncertain. ""I will have to give a book a lot of thought
column2: he finally said. Two days later
column3: he telephoned me to meet him again at the Black Muslim restaurant. He said
column4: ""I'll agree. I think my life story may help people to appreciate better how Mr. Muhammad salvages black people. But I don't want my motives for this misinterpreted by anybody -- the Nation of Islam must get every penny that might come to me."" Of course
column5: Mr. Muhammad's agreement would be necessary
column6: and I would have to ask Mr. Muhammad myself.

column1: So I flew again to see Mr. Muhammad
column4: where the Nation of Islam had bought him the house in the hot
column5: dry climate that relieved his severe bronchial condition. He and I talked alone this time. He told me how his organization had come far with largely uneducated Muslims and that truly giant strides for the black man could be made if his organization were aided by some of the talents which were available in the black race. He said
column6: ""And one of our worst needs is writers"" -- but he did not press me to answer. He suddenly began coughing
column7: and rapidly grew worse and worse until I rose from my seat and went to him
column8: alarmed
column9: but he waved me away
column10: gasping that he would be all right. Between gasps
column11: he told me he felt that ""Allah approves"" the book. He said
column12: ""Malcolm is one of my most outstanding ministers."" After arranging for his chauffeur to return me to the Phoenix airport
column13: Mr. Muhammad quickly bade me good-bye and rushed from the room coughing.

column2: Malcolm X carefully read and then signed the publication contract
column3: and he withdrew from his wallet a piece of paper filled with his sprawling longhand. ""This is this book's dedication
column4: he said. I read: ""This book I dedicate to The Honorable Elijah Muhammad
column5: who found me here in America in the muck and mire of the filthiest civilization and society on this earth
column6: and pulled me out
column7: cleaned me up
column8: and stood me on my feet
column9: and made me the man that I am today.""

column1: The contract provided that all monies accruing to Malcolm X ""shall be made payable by the agent to `Muhammad's Mosque No. 2
column2: '"" but Malcolm X felt this was insufficient. He dictated to me a letter to type for his signature
column3: which I did: ""Any and all monies representing my contracted share of the financial returns should be made payable by the literary agent to Muhammad's Mosque No. 2. These payments should be mailed to the following address: Mr. Raymond Sharrieff
column6: Illinois.""

column2: this one an agreement between him and me: ""Nothing can be in this book's manuscript that I didn't say
column3: and nothing can be left out that I want in it.""

column2: I asked Malcolm X to sign for me a personal pledge that however busy he was
column3: he would give me a priority quota of his time for the planned 100
column4: 000-word ""as told to"" book which would detail his entire life. And months later
column5: in a time of strain between us
column6: I asked for -- and he gave -- his permission that at the end of the book I could write comments of my own about him which would not be subject to his review.

column1: Malcolm X promptly did begin to pay me two- and three-hour visits
column2: parking his blue Oldsmobile outside the working studio I then had in Greenwich Village. He always arrived around nine or ten at night carrying his flat tan leather briefcase which along with his scholarly look gave him a resemblance to a hardworking lawyer. Inevitably
column3: he was tired after his long busy day
column4: and sometimes he was clearly exhausted.

column1: We got off to a very poor start. To use a word he liked
column2: I think both of us were a bit ""spooky."" Sitting right there and staring at me was the fiery Malcolm X who could be as acid toward Negroes who angered him as he was against whites in general. On television
column5: I had heard him bitterly attack other Negro writers as ""Uncle Toms
column6: ""yard Negroes
column7: ""black men in white clothes."" And there I sat staring at him
column8: proposing to spend a year plumbing his innermost secrets when he had developed a near phobia for secrecy during his years of crime and his years in the Muslim hierarchy. My twenty years in military service and my Christian religious persuasion didn't help
column9: either; he often jeered publicly at these affiliations for Negroes. And although he now would indirectly urge me to write for national magazines about the Muslims
column10: he had told me several times
column11: in various ways
column12: that ""you blacks with professional abilities of any kind will one of these days wake up and find out that you must unite under the leadership of The Honorable Elijah Muhammad for your own salvation."" Malcolm X was also convinced that the F.B.I. had ""bugged"" my studio; he probably suspected that it may even have been done with my cooperation. For the first several weeks
column13: he never entered the room where we worked without exclaiming
column14: ""Testing
column15: testing -- one
column16: two
column17: three. . . . ""

column1: Tense incidents occurred. One night a white friend was in the studio when Malcolm X arrived a little earlier than anticipated
column2: and they passed each other in the corridor. Malcolm X's manner during all of that session suggested that his worst doubts had been confirmed. Another time when Malcolm X sat haranguing me about the glories of the Muslim organization
column3: he was gesturing with his passport in his hand; he saw that I was trying to read its perforated number and suddenly he thrust the passport toward me
column4: his neck flushed reddish: ""Get the number straight
column5: but it won't be anything the white devil doesn't already know. He issued me the passport.""

column1: For perhaps a month I was afraid we weren't going to get any book. Malcolm X was still stiffly addressing me as ""Sir!"" and my notebook contained almost nothing but Black Muslim philosophy
column3: and the ""evils"" of ""the white devil."" He would bristle when I tried to urge him that the proposed book was his life. I was thinking that I might have to advise the publisher that I simply couldn't seem to get through to my subject when the first note of hope occurred. I had noticed that while Malcolm X was talking
column4: he often simultaneously scribbled with his red-ink ball-point pen on any handy paper. Sometimes it was the margin of a newspaper he brought in
column5: sometimes it was on index cards that he carried in the back of a small
column6: redbacked appointment book. I began leaving two white paper napkins by him every time I served him more coffee
column7: and the ruse worked when he sometimes scribbled on the napkins
column8: which I retrieved when he left. Some examples are these:

column4: who killed all the RM."" (Decoding that wasn't difficult knowing Malcolm X. ""YM"" was for yellow man
column6: ""WM"" for white man
column7: and ""RM"" was for red man.)

column1: Nothing ever happened without cause. Cause BM condition WM won't face. WM obsessed with hiding his guilt.""
If Christianity had asserted itself in Germany
column2: six million Jews would have lived.""

column1: WM so quick to tell BM `Look what I have done for you!' No! Look what you have done to us!""
BM dealing with WM who put our eyes out
column2: now he condemns us because we cannot see.""

column1: Only persons really changed history those who changed men's thinking about themselves. Hitler as well as Jesus
column2: Stalin as well as Buddha . . . Hon. Elijah Muhammad. . . .""

column1: It was through a clue from one of the scribblings that finally I cast a bait that Malcolm X took. ""Woman who cries all the time is only because she knows she can get away with it
column2: he had scribbled. I somehow raised the subject of women. Suddenly
column3: between sips of coffee and further scribbling and doodling
column4: he vented his criticisms and skepticisms of women. ""You never can fully trust any woman
column5: he said. ""I've got the only one I ever met whom I would trust seventy-five percent. I've told her that."" he said. ""I've told her like I tell you I've seen too many men destroyed by their wives
column6: or their women.

column3: ""not even myself. I have seen too many men destroy themselves. Other people I trust from not at all to highly
column4: like The Honorable Elijah Muhammad."" Malcolm X looked squarely at me. ""You I trust about twenty-five percent.""

column1: Trying to keep Malcolm X talking
column2: I mined the woman theme for all it was worth. Triumphantly
column4: ""Do you know why Benedict Arnold turned traitor -- a woman!"" He said
column6: I don't care who the woman is
column7: it starts with her being vain. I'll prove it
column8: something you can do anytime you want
column9: and I know what I'm talking about
column10: I've done it. You think of the hardest-looking
column11: meanest-acting woman you know
column12: one of those women who never smiles. Well
column13: every day you see that woman you look her right in the eyes and tell her `I think you're beautiful
column14: ' and you watch what happens. The first day she may curse you out
column15: the second day
column16: too -- but you watch
column17: you keep on
column18: after a while one day she's going to start smiling just as soon as you come in sight.""

column1: When Malcolm X left that night
column2: I retrieved napkin scribblings that further documented how he could be talking about one thing and thinking of something else:

column1: Negroes have too much righteousness. WM says
column3: how do I get those couple of thousand BM on it off?'""

column2: or even if she doesn't she at least pretends.""

column1: BM struggle never gets open support from abroad it needs unless BM first forms own united front.""

column2: talk with people with brains I respect
column3: all of us want same thing

column1: Would be shocking to reveal names of the BM leaders who have secretly met with THEM."" (The capitalized letters stood for The Honorable Elijah Muhammad.)

column2: Malcolm X arrived nearly out on his feet from fatigue. For two hours
column3: he paced the floor delivering a tirade against Negro leaders who were attacking Elijah Muhammad and himself. I don't know what gave me the inspiration to say once when he paused for breath
column4: ""I wonder if you'd tell me something about your mother?""

column2: and the look he shot at me made me sense that somehow the chance question had hit him. When I look back at it now
column3: I believe I must have caught him so physically weak that his defenses were vulnerable.
now walking in a tight circle. ""She was always standing over the stove
column4: trying to stretch whatever we had to eat. We stayed so hungry that we were dizzy. I remember the color of dresses she used to wear -- they were a kind of faded-out gray. . . ."" And he kept on talking until dawn
column5: so tired that the big feet would often almost stumble in their pacing. From this stream-of-consciousness reminiscing I finally got out of him the foundation for this book's beginning chapters
column6: ""Nightmare"" and ""Mascot."" After that night
column7: he never again hesitated to tell me even the most intimate details of his personal life
column8: over the next two years. His talking about his mother triggered something.

column1: Malcolm X's mood ranged from somber to grim as he recalled his childhood. I remember his making a great point of how he learned what had been a cardinal awareness of his ever since: ""It's the hinge that squeaks that gets the grease."" When his narration reached his moving to Boston to live with his half-sister Ella
column2: Malcolm X began to laugh about how ""square"" he had been in the ghetto streets. ""Why
column3: I'm telling you things I haven't thought about since then!"" he would exclaim. Then it was during recalling the early Harlem days that Malcolm X really got carried away. One night
column6: he jumped up from his chair and
column7: incredibly
column8: the fearsome black demagogue was scat-singing and popping his fingers
column9: ""re-bop-de-bop-blap-blam -- "" and then grabbing a vertical pipe with one hand (as the girl partner) he went jubilantly lindy-hopping around
column10: his coattail and the long legs and the big feet flying as they had in those Harlem days. And then almost as suddenly
column11: Malcolm X caught himself and sat back down
column12: and for the rest of that session he was decidedly grumpy. Later on in the Harlem narrative
column13: he grew somber again. ""The only thing I considered wrong was what I got caught doing wrong. I had a jungle mind
column14: I was living in a jungle
column15: and everything I did was done by instinct to survive."" But he stressed that he had no regrets about his crimes
column16: ""because it was all a result of what happens to thousands upon thousands of black men in the white man's Christian world.""

column1: His enjoyment resumed when the narrative entered his prison days. ""Let me tell you how I'd get those white devil convicts and the guards
column3: to do anything I wanted. I'd whisper to them
column5: I'll start a rumor that you're really a light Negro just passing as white.' That shows you what the white devil thinks about the black man. He'd rather die than be thought a Negro!"" He told me about the reading he had been able to do in prison: ""I didn't know what I was doing
column6: but just by instinct I liked the books with intellectual vitamins."" And another time: ""In the hectic pace of the world today
column7: there is no time for meditation
column8: or for deep thought. A prisoner has time that he can put to good use. I'd put prison second to college as the best place for a man to go if he needs to do some thinking. If he's motivated
column9: in prison he can change his life.""

column3: ""Once a man has been to prison
column4: he never looks at himself or at other people the same again. The `squares' out here whose boat has been in smooth waters all the time turn up their noses at an ex-con. But an ex-con can keep his head up when the `squares' sink.""

column1: He scribbled that night (I kept both my notebooks and the paper napkins dated): ""This WM created and dropped A-bomb on non-whites; WM now calls `Red' and lives in fear of other WM he knows may bomb us.""
Also: ""Learn wisdom from the pupil of the eye that looks upon all things and yet to self is blind. Persian poet.""

column2: Malcolm X would make a great point of stressing to me
column4: I don't want anything in this book to make it sound that I think I'm somebody important."" I would assure him that I would try not to
column5: and that in any event he would be checking the manuscript page by page
column6: and ultimately the galley proofs. At other times
column7: he would end an attack upon the white man and
column8: watching me take the notes
column9: exclaim. ""That devil's not going to print that
column10: I don't care what he says!"" I would point out that the publishers had made a binding contract and had paid a sizable sum in advance. Malcolm X would say
column11: ""You trust them
column12: and I don't. You studied what he wanted you to learn about him in schools
column13: I studied him in the streets and in prison
column14: where you see the truth.""

column1: Experiences which Malcolm X had had during a day could flavor his interview mood. The most wistful
column2: tender anecdotes generally were told on days when some incident had touched him. Once
column4: he told me that he had learned that a Harlem couple
column6: had named their newborn son ""Malcolm"" after him. ""What do you know about that?"" he kept exclaiming. And that was the night he went back to his own boyhood again and this time recalled how he used to lie on his back on Hector's Hill and think. That night
column7: too: ""I'll never forget the day they elected me the class president. A girl named Audrey Slaugh
column8: whose father owned a car repair shop
column9: nominated me. And a boy named James Cotton seconded the nomination. The teacher asked me to leave the room while the class voted. When I returned I was the class president. I couldn't believe it.""

column1: Any interesting book which Malcolm X had read could get him going about his love of books. ""People don't realize how a man's whole life can be changed by one book."" He came back again and again to the books that he had studied when in prison. ""Did you ever read The Loom of Language?"" he asked me and I said I hadn't. ""You should. Philology
column2: it's a tough science -- all about how words can be recognized
column3: no matter where you find them. Now
column6: in Latin it's pronounced like `Kaiser
column7: ' with a hard C. But we anglicize it by pronouncing a soft C. The Russians say `Czar' and mean the same thing. Another Russian dialect says `Tsar.' Jakob Grimm was one of the foremost philologists
column8: I studied his `Grimm's Law' in prison -- all about consonants. Philology is related to the science of etymology
column9: dealing in root words. I dabbled in both of them.""

column1: When I turn that page in my notebook

column1: It made me face something about myself
column2: Malcolm X said. ""My mind had closed about our mother. I simply didn't feel the problem could be solved
column3: so I had shut it out. I had built up subconscious defenses. The white man does this. He shuts out of his mind
column4: and he builds up subconscious defenses against anything he doesn't want to face up to. I've just become aware how closed my mind was now that I've opened it up again. That's one of the characteristics I don't like about myself. If I meet a problem I feel I can't solve
column5: I shut it out. I make believe that it doesn't exist. But it exists.""

column1: It was my turn to be deeply touched. Not long afterward

column6: and her memory is better than mine and she looks young and healthy. She has more of her teeth than those who were instrumental in sending her to the institution.""

column1: Anytime the name of the present Federal Judge Thurgood Marshall was raised

column8: I'm an extremist. The black race here in North America is in extremely bad condition. You show me a black man who isn't an extremist and I'll show you one who needs psychiatric attention!""

column2: motorists along the highway would wave to Malcolm X

""You are the man who has said `All Negroes are angry and I am the angriest of all'; is that correct?"" asked Harvey

column8: riveted.

column1: We had ridden to Philadelphia in reserved parlor car seats. ""I can't get caught on a coach

column13: sure

column3: Malcolm X slashed at the government's reluctance to take positive steps in the Negro's behalf. I gather that even the White House took notice
column4: for not long afterward I left off interviewing Malcolm X for a few days and went to the White House to do a Playboy interview of the then White House Press Secretary Pierre Salinger
column5: who grimaced spontaneously when I said I was writing the life story of Malcolm X. Another time I left Malcolm X to interview the U.S. Nazi Party Commander George Lincoln Rockwell
column6: who frankly stated that he admired the courage of Malcolm X
column7: and he felt that the two of them should speak together across the United States
column8: and they could thus begin a real solution to the race problem -- one of voluntary separation of the white and black races
column9: with Negroes returning to Africa. I reported this to Malcolm X
column10: who snorted
column11: ""He must think I'm nuts! What am I going to look like going speaking with a devil!"" Yet another time
column12: I went off to Atlanta and interviewed for Playboy Dr. Martin Luther King. He was privately intrigued to hear little-known things about Malcolm X that I told him; for publication
column13: he discussed him with reserve

column15: Malcolm X said drily

column17: I deduced that he actually had a reluctant admiration for Dr. King.)

column1: Malcolm X's growing respect for individual whites seemed to be reserved for those who ignored on a personal basis the things he said about whites and who jousted with him as a man. He

column4: he told me. ""I listen closely to the sound of a man's voice when he's speaking. I can hear sincerity."" The newspaper person whom he ultimately came to admire probably more than any other was the New York Times' M. S. Handler. (I was very happy when I learned that Handler had agreed to write this book's Introduction; I know that Malcolm X would have liked that.) The first time I ever heard Malcolm X speak of Handler
column6: he began

column8: from the Times --"" he resumed. Malcolm X's respect for the man steadily increased

column14: closely.""

column1: Jet magazine reported Malcolm X's trip to Selma

column5: urging him not to incite any incidents and cautioning him that his presence could cause violence. ""He listened with a smile

column8: who accompanied Malcolm X to a Negro church where he would address a mass meeting. ""Remember this: nobody puts words in my mouth

column10: Malcolm X was seated on the platform next to Mrs. Martin Luther King
column11: to whom he leaned and whispered that he was ""trying to help

column14: but that he was trying to make it easier. . . . Later

column4: that he could consider himself officially barred forever from France as ""an undesirable person."" He was asked to leave -- and he did

column1: Malcolm X returned to New York City on Saturday
column2: February 13th. He was asleep with his family when at about a quarter of three the following Sunday morning
column3: a terrifying blast awakened them. Sister Betty would tell me later that Malcolm X
column4: barking commands and snatching up screaming
column6: got the family safely out of the back door into the yard. Someone had thrown flaming Molotov cocktail gasoline bombs through the front picture window. It took the fire department an hour to extinguish the flames. Half the house was destroyed. Malcolm X had no fire insurance.

column2: distraught Sister Betty and the four little daughters went to the home of close friends. Malcolm X steeled himself to catch a plane as scheduled that morning to speak in Detroit. He wore an open-necked sweater shirt under his suit. Immediately afterward

column4: ""My house was bombed by the Muslims!"" And he hinted at revenge. ""There are hunters; there are also those who hunt the hunters!""
